definition: A planet that orbits a star outside our Solar System. These distant worlds vary widely in size, composition, and conditions, offering clues about the diversity of planets in the universe.
The main star that a planet orbits. It provides light, heat, and gravitational stability to its planetary system.
The count of stars in a planetary system. While most systems have one star, some contain two (binary) or more stars orbiting together.

The technique scientists use to detect exoplanets. Common methods include the Transit Method (watching a planet pass in front of a star) and the Radial Velocity Method (detecting tiny wobbles in a star's movement).
The telescope, satellite, or observatory that was used to discover the exoplanet or star system, such as NASA’s Kepler or the Gaia observatory.
The time it takes for a planet to complete one full orbit around its host star, usually measured in Earth days or years.

The average distance between a planet and its star, representing half the longest diameter of the orbit. It's commonly measured in Astronomical Units (AU), where 1 AU is the distance between Earth and the Sun.
The amount of matter contained in an object, such as a planet or star. It is often compared to Earth’s mass for planets or the Sun’s mass for stars.
A measure of how stretched an orbit is. An eccentricity of 0 means a perfect circle, while values closer to 1 mean the orbit is more elongated or oval-shaped.
A classification system for stars based on their temperature and color, ranging from hot, blue stars to cooler, red stars. It gives insight into the star's energy, age, and composition.
The surface temperature of a star, measured in Kelvin (K). It determines the star's color—hotter stars appear blue, cooler stars appear red.
The size of a star, usually compared to the Sun’s radius. Larger stars are generally more luminous but may have shorter lifespans.
The total mass of a star, typically measured in Solar masses (compared to the Sun). A star’s mass affects its brightness, lifespan, and ability to form planets.
The proportion of elements in a star that are heavier than hydrogen and helium. Higher metallicity often means a greater chance of forming planets, especially rocky ones.
A measure of a star’s brightness as observed by the Gaia space observatory. Lower values indicate brighter stars, while higher values mean dimmer stars.
